section-block.rac_essential-question: What do we do during the day and at night?

section-block.rac_book_summary: Rabbit lives on the moon and has the responsibility of turning wishes into stars. But Rabbit has his own wish. One night that wish comes true.

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Nn, Ii, Cc Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: Say a word. Have children choose the matching card: Nut, nest, Iguana, insect, Car, cat. Invite children to say rhyming words for cat.
Invite children to sing “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.” Have children flutter their hands to show twinkle. Note the rhyming words: star and are; high and sky.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Rabbit Moon, written and illustrated by Jean Kim.

Pablo knows that some people think they see a man’s face when they look at the moon and call it the Man in the Moon. Some people think they see the shape of a rabbit. Pablo can’t wait to find out about Rabbit Moon.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What wonderful things does Rabbit do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look! Raccoon is writing wishes. Where do you think he’s sending his paper plane wishes?
Rabbit has turned the wishes into stars! Can you make your hands move as if they were twinkling like the stars?
It looks like Rabbit made a wish, too. Where do you think Rabbit is going?
Oh no! Where have all the stars gone? What do you think Rabbit will have to do?
Let’s find the end mark, the period, that ends this sentence. The period tells us to stop reading.
Rabbit is looking through a telescope. Can you put your hands together and pretend you are looking through a telescope? What do you see?
This page says “A sweet surprise!” What is the sweet surprise?
Which meaning of the word sweet does the author use here? Does sweet mean “nice” or “a taste that is not sour”?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What wonderful things does Rabbit do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Rabbit fills the sky with stars.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about what the animals do during the day.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Rabbit do with wishes?
Why do you think the book is called Rabbit Moon?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Singing with Young Children
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Singing with children is fun and a powerful tool in helping to support their early brain and language development. Music introduces them to words and sound patterns. This helps develop listening and comprehension skills, which are necessary foundation for learning how to read.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Take Responsibility for Materials and Jobs
section-block.rac_body-text: Ask “What would you do if...” questions to help children explore being responsible for materials and jobs. What would you do if you spilled paint on the floor? What would you do if you forgot to feed the fish when it was your turn? What would you do if a puzzle piece was missing? (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about our Mind Builder and see how Rabbit takes responsibility for the stars and does his very important job.
Clifford has a job, too! His job is to help us as we reread the narrative. And he loves his job!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages in the story where the clues help us identify when Rabbit is being responsible.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer the questions that follow.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Rabbit stirs the wishes with care. He is very gentle and tries not tohurt them. Let’s stir the wishes with care like Rabbit does.
What does he turn the wishes into?
What does Rabbit do with the stars? How is Rabbit showing responsibility? (MB)
Which letter is added to the word star to show it means more than one star?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Now let’s see what Rabbit is doing. What do we see Rabbit doing with his new friends? (MB)
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What happened to all of the stars in the sky? It says “Rabbit knows what must be done.” What do you think Rabbit needs to do? (MB)
What do we see Rabbit doing? It says “there’s work to be done.” What work does Rabbit need to do? Are the stars Rabbit’s responsibility? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to act out the following classroom situations as you narrate them.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s paint at this easel. Uh-oh! The paint dripped on the floor. Let’s get a towel to clean it up. That’s nice. Now we can paint some more. Uh- oh! It’s time to stop. Let’s close all the paint jars with care. Let’s put our brushes in the sink. We really know how to be responsible for classroom materials. (MB)
section.rac_body-text: Continue with scenarios about snack time and playing in the block corner.
Transcribe children’s speech as they share things they do during the day after school.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Entrusting children with classroom jobs fosters community and develops responsibility, which leads to a sense of autonomy and pride. Letting children help create the job list and construct the anchor chart or binder is a step toward this goal. (Wilson/ Responsiveclassroom.org/Classroom Jobs)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 1: Day and Night

section-block.rac_body-text: Show the moon on pages 24 and 25. Ensure that children understand that the moon isn’t changing; instead, the sun’s light makes it look smaller or bigger.
Form groups of four. Three children stand together to be Earth. One child orbits them as the moon and says, “Round and round Earth I go. I am the moon, as you know!”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Rabbit Moon, written by Jean Kim.
Pablo loves reading narratives like this one, which is about a rabbit who lives on the moon.
This is the question I want you to think about as we read today: What do the animals see in the nighttime sky?

section.rac_body-text: Reread the book and the Day 3 prompts Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you see on the cover? How do you know it is nighttime?
The wishes travel across the sky. They go on a journey, or a long trip.
Who can tell me what they see in this nighttime sky?
Look at how many stars there are twinkling in the night sky. What else do the animals see in the night sky?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What letter and sound does the word night begin with?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s look at the moon. Here it is a full moon. Make a shape with your hands that looks like a full moon.
Here I see a half moon. Make a shape with your hands that looks like a half moon.
What does the moon look like here? Have you ever seen a crescent moon that looks like this?
What is missing from the nighttime sky? What will Rabbit have to do?
Did you think about the information you read in the book today? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do the animals see in the nighttime sky?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to write about what people see in a nighttime sky.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What kind of moon do the animals see in the nighttime sky?
The animals see a f_____ (full) moon.
The animals see a full moon.
Why do we only see the stars at nighttime?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children should learn basic terms and phrases used in science. The National Center for Improving Science Education has a list of concepts that young children should learn before embarking on their scientific learning. Explain how a scientific model represents other things.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR EARTH | WEEK 1: Day and Night

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children stand and face you. Ask them to pretend you are the sun shining light on them. Then ask children to slowly turn so they are facing the other direction. Ask if they can see your light shining on them now. Explain that the sun is always in the sky, but when Earth turns, it no longer gets light from the sun. Explain that is what makes day and night.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read the Big Chart of Big Ideas called Daytime/Nighttime. It is a poster with informational text.
Pablo loves to look at informational posters and learn about daytime and nighttime.
The book Rabbit Moon and Daytime/Nighttime each show something about day or night.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What do we do during the day and at night?
section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Day and Night
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the poster together.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This poster shows three places in the daytime and in the nighttime.
What do you notice about daytime in the mountains? In the nighttime? When do you see stars?
Which letter is added to the word mountain to show it means more than one mountain?
What do you see in the daytime in the country? In the nighttime? When do you see the sun?
What do you notice about daytime in the city? In the nighttime? When is it dark outside?
Would you look up in the daytime or in the nighttime to see the Rabbit Moon?

section.rac_body-text: Have children use play items to pretend that it is daytime in the mountains, country, and city. Have them repeat, pretending that it is nighttime. Remind children as they participate that it is their responsibility to not take someone else’s things. (MB)
Provide a writing prompt about day or night and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The Chinese language has no plural words, so children whose home language is Chinese may have difficulties initially with changing words from singular to plural. In Chinese, a number word is placed in front of the noun and the noun remains singular. Reinforce the -s sound at the end of plural words so children can begin to hear it and recognize its importance in forming plural words in English.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to say this nursery rhyme: Star light, star bright, first star I have seen tonight. I wish I may, I wish I might, have this wish I wish tonight. Identify the rhymes.
Invite children to close their eyes and pretend to make a wish on a star. Invite any children who would like to share their wish to do so.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell the book Rabbit Moon by Jean Kim.
This narrative is fiction. Fiction means that it is an imaginary story. Pablo loves to read narratives about rabbits!
This week we read about a rabbit who lives on the moon and turns wishes into stars. Today, think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What might we see in the sky at night?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to activity participate in the prompts below.
Remind children as they participate it is their responsibility to control their bodies. (MB)
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is Rabbit doing? Can you pretend to stir the wishes?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What letter and sound does the word into begin with?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend to toss the stars up into the nighttime sky to fill the sky with light.
It’s time for an adventure. Where is Rabbit going for his adventure?
What do you see in this nighttime sky? Let’s be twinkling stars and move about in the nighttime sky. Remember to move carefully and resist touching any other stars. (MB)
Let’s look up and wave to the rabbit in the moon. If you ever get a chance to look up at the moon, see if you can see Rabbit!
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What might we see in the sky at night?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We might see a full moon.
We might see a half moon.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about their day at school and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Would you see the sun or stars in the sky at night?
I might see st______ (stars) in the sky at night.
I might see stars in the sky at night.
Why do you see different things in the sky at different times?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Role-play is an important part of child development. It builds confidence and creativity, supports physical development, and develops problem solving and communication skills. It is a fun activity that allows children to get into character and act out real-life or fictional roles.
